editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SISTERS, A COMEDIE, AS It was acted at the private Houſe IN BLACK FRYERS,
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Robinſon at the Three Pigeons, and Humphrey Moſeley at the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1652.

div.head: To the moſt worthily Honoured William Paulet Eſquire.
div.p:
COmpoſitions of this nature, have heretofore been graced by the acceptance, and protection of the greateſt Nobility (I may ſay Princes) but in this age, when the Scene of Drammatick Poetry is changed into a wilderneſs, it is hard to find a patron to a legitimate muſe. Many that were wont to encourage Poems, are faln beneath the proverbiall want of the compoſers, and by their ruins are only at leaſure to take meaſure with their eye, of what they have been. Some extinguiſhed with their fortune, have this happineſs, to be out of capacity of further ſhipwrack, while their ſad remaynes peep out of the ſea, and may ſerve naked marks, and caution to other Navigators, Malignant ſtars the while! In this unequall condition of the time, give me leave to congratulate my own felicity, that hath directed this Comedy unto you, who wear your nobleneſs with more ſecurity, than titles, and a name that continues bright and impaſsible among the conſtellations in our Sphear of Engliſh honour. I 〈1 page missing〉
dare not detain you, Sir, with too long a Preface; if you pleaſe to entertain theſe Papers, as the modeſt tender of my ſervice, I ſhall receive it as a moſt kind influence upon me; and you will engage to all your commands, the humble heart of

lg.l: DOes this look like a Term? I cannot tell,
Our Poet thinks the whole Town is not well,
Has took ſome Phyſick lately, and for fear
Of catching cold dares not ſalute this Ayr.
But ther's another reaſon, I hear ſay
London is gone to York, 'tis a great way;
Pox o'the Proverb, and of him ſay I,
That look'd ore Lincoln, cauſe that was, muſt we
Be now tranſlated North? I could rail to
On Gammar Shiptons Ghoſt, but 't wo' not doe,
The Town will ſtill be flecking, and a Play
Though ne'r ſo new, will ſtarve the ſecond day:
Upon theſe very hard conditions,
Our Poet will not purchaſe many Towns;
And if you leave us too, we cannot thrive,
I'l promiſe neither Play nor Poet live
Till ye come back, think what you do, you ſee
What audience we have, what Company
"To Shakeſpear comes, whoſe mirth did once beguile
"Dull hours, and buskind, made even ſorrow ſmile,
"So lovely were the wounds, that men would ſay
"They could endure the bleeding a whole day:
He has but few friends lately, think o'that,
Hee'l come no more, and others have his fate.
"Fletcher the Muſes darling, and choice love
"Of Phoebus, the delight of every Grove;
"Vpon whoſe head the Laurel grew, whoſe wit
"Was the Times wonder, and example yet,
'Tis within memory, Trees did not throng,
As once the Story ſaid to Orpheus ſong.
"Johnſon, t' whoſe name, wiſe Art did bow, and Wit
"Is only juſtified by honouring it:
"To hear whoſe touch, how would the learned Quire
"With ſilence ſtoop? and when he took his Lyre,
"Apollo dropt his Lute, aſham'd to ſee
"A Rival to the God of Harmonie.
You do forſake him too, we muſt deplore
This fate, fot we do know it by our door.
How muſt this Author fear then, with his guilt
Of weakneſs to thrive here, where late was ſpilt
The Muſes own blood, if being but a few,
You not conſpire, and meet more frequent too?
There are not now nine Muſes, and you may
Be kind to ours, if not, he bad me ſay,
Though while you careleſs kill the reſt, and laugh,
Yet he may live to write your Epitaph.

list.item: Pulcheria diſguiſed, and under the name of vergerid

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Frapolo, Longino, Pacheco, Rangone, Strozzo, and other Banditi.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: I Like not this laſt Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: It ſtartled me to read it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Did you read? tis a fault Strozzo a fault
I'l have no theef hereafter learn to read;
Threaten us with long winded Proclamations?
We are ſafe within our Woods, and Territories,
And are above his Edicts; Have not wee
A Common-wealth among our ſelves, ye Tripolites?
A Common-wealth? a Kingdom; and I am
The Prince of Qui-Vala's, your Sovereign theef,
And you are all my Subjects.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: We are—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And is there one ſo baſe to change Complexion,
Becauſe we are proſcrib'd? I'l be no Prince.
I have a grudging on me to be honeſt,
And leave you to the fear of hemp, and hunger;
Have I by ſtratagems ſo oft preſerv'd you,
When you were howling out your lives, and lead
A way in Dog-couples by ruſty Officers?
And are you ſtruck dead with a Paper pellet?
Your bloud turn'd Whay, becauſe there is reward
Promis'd to bring our heads in? I renounce you—
Land Rats—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Frapolo, they recant;
A little humane frailty may be pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Shall theeves, whoſe predeceſſors have been Kings,
And conquer'd worlds, be factious, and ſchiſmaticall?
I ſpeak not for my ſelf, but your own ſakes,
Whoſe Impudence, and art in valiant theft,
Hereafter, may advance you to be Princes.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You have confirmed us.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You were beſt be rogues, and one betray another,
To get the baſe reward; do, loſe your honour,
Live branded, and be pointed at i'th ſtreet,
There goes a Raſcall that betrai'd his Prince,
Or cut the throat of his Comrade, this will
Shew well i'th'Chronicles— Stand fair you varlets,
Becauſe we cannot tell whoſe heart is treacherous,
I will examine all your Phiſnomies,
And in whoſe face ſoever I can find
A ſcandalous line, or look that may beget
Suſpition of a Man that wo'not die
An honourable Rebell, and defie
The Laws, I'le ſhoot him preſently.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Hang Laws,
And thoſe that make'em, Conſcience is a Varlet;
Stand fair and ſhew complexions.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ye are all valiant, honeſt theeve landers,
And I will be your Prince agen, and dy w'ee,
As boldly, as they dare invent—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hang Cowards.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I will not have you theeves among your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: How's that, and pleaſe thy Excellence, not theeves?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Not theeves one to another; but Religious—
There is a kind of a Religion
We Outlaws muſt obſerve.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: I never knew
Religion yet, and 'twill be now unſeaſonable
To learn.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I'l be of no Religion.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who was ſo bold
To ſay he would have no Religion?
What man is he, hopes to be drunk, to whore,
To ſc • pe the wheels, the Gallies, and the gallowes
And be of no Religion?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He ſays right.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yee ſhall be of what Religion I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Tis fit we ſhould, Frapolo is our Monarch.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And yet I muſt conſider of ſome fit one
That ſhall become our trade
And conſtitutions; hum! Silence.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Nay, nay Prince, take time to think on't,
Ther's no haſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have thought,
And you ſhall be no Pagans, Jews, nor Chriſtians.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: But every man ſhall be of all Religions.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I like that well.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why ſhould I clog your Conſcience, or confine it?
Do but obey your Prince, and I pronounce
You ſhall live Grandees, till the State Phangs catch you,
And when you come unto the Wheel, or Gibbet,
Bid figo for the World, and go out Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A Prince, a Prince!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Provided, that no theef
Makes a Confeſſion at his Death, or peach
His Tribe, or make a ſhew of penitence,
To make the Butter-women melt, and draw
Compaſſion from the toothleſs muſty rabble;
This will exclude the benefit of that Canon
Declares you Martyrs for the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Tis a howling voice.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What Cry was that?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Of one, whoſe pocket has given up the Ghoſt,
And with the fear his body ſhould do ſo,
He howles O'this faſhion.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Bring him to our preſence.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Gentlemen, tis very cold, I beſeech you
Do not ſtrip my Skin off, you are not ſure
I ſhall go to a fire when I go out of
This World; and yet as I am, I confeſſe
I ſhall yield very little burn'd.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Knock out his brains.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Piſtoll him.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Cut's throat.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Gentlemen, hear me— I am very ſorry,
I had no greater ſum— but if you pleaſe
To reprieve a poor wretch, I may do you ſervice,
And if you knew my inclination,
You would not be too Cruell.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: To what are you inclin'd Sirra?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have been commended for a Dexterity
At your fellonious trade; for Gentlemen,
I have been a Pickpocket of a child, and have
Theſe many years been thought a pretty houſe-theef,
Mary I have not yet breeding abroad
With ſuch deſerving men, but I ſhall be
Moſt glad to learn, and if you pleaſe t' accept
Me to your tribe, I have Intelligence
Where money lyes hid, and very few Spirits
To guard it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Be confident, and be cover'd.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Let him be one of us.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Be brief, where is this treaſure?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have an old Father, and Mother, Gentlemen,
Pleaſe you beſtow a viſit upon them;
They have ſome Goldfinches, having new ſold
A peece of Land, was given 'em by the rich
Vincenzo, Father to the famous, proud
Paulina, now his heir.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: The glorious Daughter
Of old Vincenzo? ſhe's a Semiramis.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The very ſame; if you would viſit her,
I am acquainted with the houſe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Wee'l take a time to think on her; to th'point.
What ready money has your Father Sirra?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Tis but two days ago ſince he receiv'd
Six hundred Piſtolets, I can direct
To a Cedar Cheſt, where the fine ſum lies dormant.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: What Servants has your Father?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Alas none, they are miſerable Hinds,
And make me all the drudge, you need not fear
The Court-du-Guard; if you pleaſe let me go
An honeſt theeves part, and furniſh me
With a Devills complexion, to hide my own,
I will conduct you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A very honeſt fellow!

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I do not love to be ingratefull where
I'm kindly us'd, my heart is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Is he thy own Father?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: My own Father and Mother Sir, the cauſe
Would not be ſo naturall elſe, and meritorious.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A precious rogue, fit him inſtantly
With a diſguiſe, and let him have that face
The Devill wore in the laſt anti-maſque.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It cannot be too ugly Sir to fright 'em.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: But if he fail in any Circumſtance—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis not far off, I know the neareſt way.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Or give the leaſt ſuſpition to betray you,
Be ſure you cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: We ſhall.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I thank You Sir, d'ee think I'l be a Traytor?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Come firſt along with us.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You heard this fellow name the proud Paulina,
Her Cheſts are worth the rifling.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Caſtle is impregnable ſhe lives in.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Was that ſpoke like an underſtanding theef,
A true Bandit? How I do bluſh for thee?
Was not the Orchard of Heſperides
Watcht by a fierce, and flaming Dragon, robd?
Shall wee deſpair to reach her golden Apples?
Wee'l make diſcovery of the place, and perſons,
Put it to Fate, let Stars do what they pleaſe;
Mercury is a Stronger theef than Hercules.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What a brave time have we had, ſince our
Old Maſter died?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Though he were a gallant man, his Daughter
Makes his Memory burn dym, and (compar'd
To her) he liv'd but like a Hermit in a Cell,
She is all Magnificent, a Bererice,
Every hair of her head worth ſtellyfying.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But my Lady, for ſo we muſt call her,
May be of kin to Lucifer for pride;
How many brave Gentlemen hath ſhe deſpis'd,
When once their bliſter of Love broke out,
And they made offer of Mariage?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Here is her Siſter Angellina a virgin
Of another conſtitution, their two natures
As different are, as the two Poles, our Miſtreſs
Cannot be ſo Tyrannically proud
As ſhe is ſweet, and humble.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That's the reaſon her Father left her only
As much as would commend her to a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Her Uncle dotes upon her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: He does love her.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Tis an old blunt brave fellow; but he has
Quite loſt our gallant Ladies good opinion,
He is out of grace.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Becauſe he would correct her inſolence,
Who oblig'd by her father to the care of
Her governour, wo'not tie up his Counſell,
Which he enforces ſometimes ſo paſſionately,
It is a ſport to hear her contempt of his gravity.
He has met my Lady, I ſee a quarrell
In their looks already, let us withd raw
Behind that Lobby, we may hear, and
Laugh ſecurely.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How long have you been ſpeechleſs? am
Not I your Uncle? why do you look ſo ſcurvily?
I do not think you are a Princeſſe yet,
And therefore take the boldneſs to ſalute you,
Without the Ceremony of Petitioners
That haunt your Ladiſhips charity; or if
You thought me deſpicable, your Siſter has
Deſerv'd your ſmile.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It may be ſo—

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Buffoones,
That make an Idoll of you, and can pawn
Their Souls to flatter you, ſhould be entertaind,
And Courted to your vanity. I bluſh for you;
Will nothing bring you into ſenſe of Honour
Or Modeſty? I ha done.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It will become you;
You do preſume too much.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Preſume? why, are
Not you Paulina am not I Antonio
Your Uncle? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do remember Sir,
I calld you ſo, while you preſerv'd your wits,
And may acknowledge you again, upon
Sober Conditions, and your Senſes perfect.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sober Conditions? am I Drunk, Gipſey?
What fleſh is able to forbear. Doſt hear?
Thou haſt drunk a Devill.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I did not ſee him in my Cup.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And he has ſweld thee to this monſtrous pride,
More than thy Sex beſide; if thou goeſt on
At this rate, thou wilt make Lucifer an Ape,
He muſt be thy Diſciple.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Old thing raves.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thing? what thing? thank heaven thou
Art a woman; I would beat thee into a Poltiſe—
When didſt thou ſay thy prayers?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You know I keep a Chaplain.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thy Soul wants deſperate lancing;
Ther's an eternall Ulcer in thy heart,
Te Witches cannot ſuck it dry, there is
A bath of Poyſon in thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I ſhall pity him;
A Poſſet, and to bed with him, his head
Does want the benefit of ſleep; how wild
The good man looks?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thou art—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Miſtreſs of this Caſtle as I take it,
Without your Legacy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I could rail upon the dead for't; doſt thou not fear
Thy Fathers ghoſt ſhould haunt thee?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I never think upon him, and it was
His providence to leave me an eſtate,
To keep me from thoſe Malancholy fancies,
And I will have you my caprichious Uncle
Know, in the Circle of theſe my Dominions,
I will have no Competitor.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Dominions?
Was ever ſuch an inſolence? are not you
ome Queen conceald?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am Independent, and ſole regent here.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: So ſo,
Where's your Nobility? they are to blame
Not to attend—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Who waits?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But they do want white Staves, this is
Not State enough.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It ſhall be mended, let them be remembred.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: She's in earneſt—and
If I were worthy to adviſe you Madam,
Your grace ſhould be a little more reſerv'd,
And entertain none that did treat of Mariage
To your private conference, untill they had
In publick receiv'd audience like Ambaſſadors.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I like the Counſell well, it ſhall be ſo,
The next that comes ſhall find it my good Uncle.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: She's incorrigible.
What if you commanded thoſe that do attend
Your perſon to obſerve you on their knees
Sometimes, they muſt be humble to your highneſs;
I can forget my gray hairs, name, and bloud,
And teach your Servants duty.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The example
Will edifie the houſhold, and you may,
By fair degrees riſe to our Princely favour.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam, the Lord Contarini is arrived
The Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: He comes a woing to me, let it be
Your Office reverend Uncle to acquaint him,
Our pleaſure is to give him Audience
To Morrow in full State, untill when Uncle,
Make it your care his entertainment be
Such as becomes the greatneſs of his bloud,
And one, on whom the Prince, we know, beſtows
His ſpeciall grace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: D'ee hear ſweet Niece? be not you tranſporte
This is no dream, the man is no mock-lord.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I'l be a Princeſs here, as you directed,
If he can humble himſelf to Ceremony,
Promiſe him honourable acceſs, and freedom,
If the Conditions pleaſe him not, he may
Return, and leave our Court.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is this in Nature? well I'l follow her,
And if ſhe be not paſt all ſhame, and ſenſes,
I will humble or confound her.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Longino, Strozzo, Binding Fabio, and Morulla.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: AH ſweet Gentlemen, we are very poor,
And have a great Charge.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: We do come to eaſe you of your charge.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Pity my age.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: You muſt then pity our youth.

div.stage: Enter Piperollo viſarded with three bags.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Here, ſhare and ſhare like.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Alas we are undone.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: What ſhall we do with them?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: If you have bound her hands and feet, you
May try whether ſhe be a Witch or no, there's
A Pond in the backſide, if ſhe ſwim, ſo—
For him?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Have ſome compaſſion, tis our whole eſtate.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: You have a Son, a pious child we hear.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: He will not let you want.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Alas poor boy, he little thinks what we
• ith care and providence laid up for him
• hould thus be loſt. O pity Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Boh—Lets away.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: I begin to find a kind of a compunction,
• et us be charitable theeves for once—

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And return half,
• hat ſay you?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Not a gazet, y'are not ſuch fooliſh theeves;
• art with preſent money? part with my life firſt.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Not to your Parents?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: We uſe them well, becauſe we do not carry
Their Cowes away; there they have Cheeſe, and Butter,
Bread comes by nature, and they both can glean,
There's water in the Well too; not a penny—
If you will be ſo charitable, defalk
From your own ſhares, mine is a juſt theeves part;
I look for thanks, diſtribute your own alms;
Theſe things muſt be employ'd to better uſes.
Is a Father, and Mother conſiderable
To ready mony; oh! fie—boh!

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Then we muſt over-rule you.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Ah what do you mean?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Baul and betray your ſelf at your own perill.
We will be bold with your theeves part—
Come neerer—Look you good Woman,
You ſhall not loſe your thirds, ſay you have met
With honeſt theeves; this ſhall ſuffice at preſent,
Which we but borrow neither, that you may not
Suſpect our payment, you ſhall have ſecurity,
This honeſt man bound for't, and ſo we leave you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Tis money.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: And left one of their fellows bound.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do we not dream Wife? I dare not come neer
Him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: They are gone, I'l ſee his complexion;
Who's this?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Our own Son Piperollo?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Pray Father give me your bleſſing, ah—
Mother do not ſtone me to death with that
Money bag, I am your Son.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: My Son? I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: A liar, you know Mother, is worſe than a
Theef; do not deſtroy the hopes of your Family,
Alas, I was drawn in, and made a theef
In my own defence, they ſwore to cut my throat
Elſe, do you think I had ſo little grace—

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Did they ſo? I'l try what I can do.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Oh my quibibles! ſweet Mother, remember
You were a woman in your days, that knew
What's what, and the true difference of things.
I am a man yet, your forgiveneſſe may
Make me a true man. Libbing, and hanging
Are no helps to poſterity, I am your own
Sweet fleſh and bloud—Oh.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Kick him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I thank you, this Correction may do me good;
Gently, ah gently; ſhall I not ask you bleſſing,
A twelve-month hence?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I wo'not.
My Mother has a deadly lift with her leg.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Boh, you tadpole.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I ſhall do no good o'this trade.
Now to my wits, this is no world to ſtarve in.

div.stage: Enter Lucio, Giovanni, Stephanio, with white Staves.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is very fine; do not theſe Staves become us?
But will my Lady be thus mad, and give
The Lord Contarini Audience in ſuch State?
She takes upon her like a very Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But is't not ſtrange, her Uncle ſhould thus humor her?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: He gave her the firſt hint, which ſhe purfues
To his vexation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But will my Lord ſtoop to this mockery?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: He is prepar'd by her Uncle; 'twil be ſport,
If ſhe but carry it with pride enough.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Let her alone.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: And if my Lord wants confidence—

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I think her impudence will make him bluſh,
And put him out; I have ſeen a Counterfeit
With ſuch a Majeſty compoſe himſelf,
He thought himſelf a Prince, could frown as ſcornfully,
And give his hand out to great Lords to kiſs,
With as much grace, as all the Royall bloud
Had muſterd in his veins.

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.l: Some Monarch
Of Innes a Court in England ſure; but when
His reign expires, and Chriſtmas in the grave
Cold as the Turkies coffind up in cruſt,
That walk like Ghoſts, and glide to ſeverall Tables,
When Inſtruments are hoarſe with ſitting up,
When the gay triumph ceaſes, and the treaſure
Divided, all the Offices laid up,
And the new cloathes in Lavender, what then?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why then the man that kiſt his highneſs hand
O'r night, may juſtle him for the wall next morning,
And have it too; if he come off with all
His wits, the Play is paid for, and he fit
For travell.
sp.stage: Enter Contarini, Antonio, Vergerio, they whiſper.
sp.l: My Ladies Uncle, and the Lord Contarini.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My Lord Contarini expects when he
May have the happineſs to preſent his ſervice
To your great Lady.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: We ſhall Sir acquaint her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your Office Sir?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Her Steward.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yours I pray?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Mine, Treaſurer.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Mine, Controller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I kiſs your hands; this may be worth my Lord
Curioſity.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: For the mirths ſake, my Lord be pleas'd, you ma •
Do an act of Charity and reſtore her Senſes;
I'l wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now Vergerio?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The expectation is increas'd, her Officers
Obſerve the State; were your affections earneſt
And I my Lord your Miſtreſſe, I ſhould truſt
Her pride.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Unleſs ſhe raviſh me.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: She's upon entrance, her madneſs holds,
Your confidence may convert her, ſhees my Neece
And I am ſorry for it.

div.stage: Enter Paulina attended in State, Angellina, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Give him acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What Ladies that ſtands on her right hand?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Her younger Siſter, that does vex me as much
With her humility, as the other with
Her impudence.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: An excellent peece, Vergerio.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Which my Lord?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Madam, the glory of your time and Nation,
Whoſe looks do ſhine with Majeſty, and ſhoot
A flame t' undoe the admirer, O call in
Some beams that wait upon the thrones of light,
Or I ſhall fall your ſacrifice, and not finiſh
What my great Maſter gave me in charge.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Has the Prince a mind to her himſelf.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Tis not impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Speak on my Lord.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Gipſey, ſhe does believe the lightning 〈◊〉 her eys
Will blaſt indeed, how ſcornfully ſhe 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I come from the great Sovereign of hearts,
Whoſe glorious monarchy uncircumſcrib'd,
Extends to all the habitable world,
Where ever land or lover ſtretch'd his arm,
Whoſe Scepter's not like that of common Kings,
But a bright golden ſhaft feather'd with ſighs,
And headed with a flame, which finds acceſs,
Like ſubtill lightning to the moſt ſecure,
And ſtubborn Cell that ever yet inclos'd
A humane thought—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He flies high.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Tis his arrow—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Speak this great name.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The moſt immortall Prince of Love—

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: A high and mighty Prince indeed.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Tis not our Prince of Parma then?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Unto your beauty Madam, that makes ſweet
The breath of Fame, in his name I am ſent
To offer up a Servant, rich with wonder,
And humble thoughts that honour you; who can
See thoſe perfections and not adore
The Divine Owner? Brightneſs that offends
The inhocent eye that gazes, is in you
The cure of blindneſs, and the filmes that hang
Upon the humble ſight, fall off and vaniſh,
That it may take new life and light from you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is ſhe not yet ridiculous to her ſelf?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I can leave Cupids Court to live with you,
And all thoſe bowers, where an eternall ſpring
Makes every flower in love with it's own beauty.
The wind whoſe airy wings convey all ſweetneſs
That ſenſe can entertain, I would exchange
But to be near your breath; and think there dwels
A harmony in your voice, above the airs
Of all thoſe charming Birds by love ſelected
From every wood to be his quire. I fear
I am too bold, and may be thought to wander;
If Madam you accept my amorous vows,
Which live yet in the weak expreſſion
Of him that honours you, time will produce
A white and fortunate hour to crown our loves
With nuptiall happineſs.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You have relation
To the Court of Parma, your name Lord
Contarini, you have no Meſſage from you Maſter?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Madam your ſame hath fild his Court, and he
Preſents by me his Princely wiſhes of
Your happineſs, and ſhould he ſee your perſon,
Like mine, his heart I fear would melt into
A ſtream of Love and Admiration.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sir, we accept in good part greeting from
The Prince, but you have no commiſſion
To treat for him; the ſubſtance of your own
Affair will ask our pauſe, we will take time
To anſwer, which till you receive, you may
Command our Court.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Proud folly!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prodigious impudence!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What think you Signior?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am confounded, I'l to her agen.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: When ſhall I awake?
This ſure is but a dream, the Gentleman
Cannot ſo much miſtake his time and Language.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I came with Curioſity to ſee
Her pride ſo talk'd of, but my heart I feel
Is taken with an object of true ſweetneſs.
Is't not a lovely figure? ſay Vergerio.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If but her mind anſwer that fair proportion,
My Lord ſhe is worth love, but being Siſter
To a woman of ſuch pride—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I prethee leave me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: She is very beautifull; my Lord is taken.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lady, but that ther's ſtory for your births,
I ſhould make judgment by your modeſt face,
This arrogant woman could not be your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sir, if your expectation be not anſwered
With her full worth, I ſhall beſeech you name her
With leſs diſgrace, (our bloud ſo neer) it cannot
Be gratefull to my ear, to hear her blemiſhes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I was prepar'd before to meet this goodneſs;
Theſe words and looks become that innocent ſpring
From whence they flow, vertue hath ſuch an army
About your heart, ther's nothing can approach
Ill to betray it, or proceed from you
But warranted by honour.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I know not,
But ſure my Lord, you talk too fine a language
For me to underſtand; we are far from Court,
Where though you may ſpeak Truth, you cloath it with
Such trim and gay apparell, we that only
Know her in plainneſs, and ſimplicity,
Cannot tell how to truſt our ears, or know,
When men diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: By your own love
To truth, you muſt beleeve me, when I ſay,
Although it took beginning from this viſit,
I love no beauty but your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You ſaid you lov'd my Siſter, and expreſt
Your paſſion in ſuch mighty phraſe and fancie
I thought your ſoul had made a buſineſs on't,
Pardon the weakneſs of my faith if I
Dare not believe this change.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Your Siſter, Lady,
I came to viſit, not affect, I heard,
And had a purpoſe but to try how neer
The wonder of her pride (pardon ſweet Virgin)
Came to a truth, nor did I Court her with
The language of a meaning lover; but
Prepared by your Vncle, meant to make her ſee
Her miſerable folly; I dare not
Preſent ſuch Mockeries to you; ſuſpect not
This haſty addreſs; by your fair ſelf, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My Lord, If I beleev'd this, reall Courtſhip,
I ſhould not entertain your honour with a
A fruitleſs Expectation, but declare,
Beſides my want of fortune, beauty, birth,
To make me worth your love, I am already
Contracted by my Father to Religion,
Whoſe will I cheerfully obey, and wait
When my good Uncle will diſpoſe me to
A Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Where for
So great an honour you pretend to me
A moſt unworthy maid, I'l offer up
My prayers, that you may chooſe a heart more equall
To your own love, and greatneſs.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nay you muſt
Not leave me ſo, we are interrupted, you
May truſt me fair one with a neerer Conference.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Alas poor old man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Old man before your borrowed Ladiſhip
Is bold to keep his head warm, and to tell you
You are a Puppet, take that to your title;
Of honour.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: So Sir, none reſtrain his inſolence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'l make him ſwallow down his ſtaff of Office
That ſtirs. I ha'not done. Canſt be ſo impudent
To think his Lordſhip does not laugh at thee?
Your eys the thrones of light? a brace of Lanthorns,
In which two ſnufs of Candle cloſe to th'ſocket,
Appear like fire-drakes, and will ſerve to light
A traveller into a Ditch. You Madam Majeſty,
And the glory of a Nation?
Tho'art a diſeaſe to Honour, Modeſty,
A Feaver in thy Fathers bloud, a Gangren
Upon his name, a Pox upon thee for't;
Ther's one diſeaſe more, yet I have not done.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: My Charity may invite, if theſe fits hold,
Some cloſe proviſion for you 'mong mad men;
I do command you leave my houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wo'not,
I'l fire the houſe; doſt hear? thou wo't burn well,
Th'aſt Oil enough about thy face, and all
Thy body Pitch, very combuſtible.
But I'l not be damn'd for thee, now I think on't,
And ſince no Counſell will prevail, I'l ſave
My ſelf. Before I go, give but a reaſon
Why thou doſt ſlight this gallant Lord, and ſquint
As if he were Groom or Foot man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I'l tell you,
You would have the truth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If thou canſt ſpeak any.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do eſteem my ſelf
More equall for his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who, the Prince?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No, the blind Prince of Love, you are wiſe Uncle,
But I am out of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think I were beſt cut off thy head, and ſave
The Laws a labour—Ther's no talking to her.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am of your mind Uncle, you may edifie
Your charge, my younger Siſter, ſhe's not proud,
Pray take her w'ee, ſhee'l become the Cloiſter;
Go, and be mortified together, take her,
I am weary of her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And I of thee;
She ſhall be further oft too, thou'lt infect her,
Although her fooliſh Father, (yet he was
My Brother) I have not power to ſpeak
Well o'th'dead, gave thee his whole Eſtate,
I have a fortune, doſt thou hear? I have,
And to vex thee, thy Siſter ſhall have that,
I'l ſee, and I can make her proud, I'l do't;
She ſhall have Servants, Suters, Fidlers, Flatterers,
Fine Cloathes, and all the food that can provoke
To glorifie her ſenſe; I have bags to ſpare,
She ſhall not to a Nunnery to vex thee,
I ſay again ſhe ſhall not, wee'l have humours;
The to'ther Pox upon thee, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I fear he's mad indeed. Let me have Muſick,
This talk has made me Melancholy.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: FOr thy Mothers ſake thou ſhalt be entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: An under Butler would fit me rarely,
Ther's none i'th'houſe that ſhall be ſooner drunk,
Nor oftner for my Ladies credit Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Can you write?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: And read in print Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Art thou faithfull? may a man truſt thee?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: For more than I'l ſpeak on; truſted? I was boun •
For two Gentlemen lately, that could not take up
Five hundred Piſtols upon other ſecurity,
My Father and Mother knows it; I ſhall never
Endure a theef for a thing that I know, alas
You know I am a neighbors child, my mother
Was your good Ladies nurſe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Do not I know thy Mother?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Better it may be, than I know my Father.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Till ſome Office fall i'th'houſe, you ſhall ſerve me,
And ride with me, to receive my Ladies Rents.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Mr. Steward, yonder are the rareſt fellows,
In ſuch phantaſticall habits too, they call
Themſelves Mathematicians.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What do they come for?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: To offer their ſervice to my Lady, and tell fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Have they no chief?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Yes a quaint philoſophicall fellow, they call
Him a Caldean, a great Schollar, they do
Not come for money like your ſtarch'd fac'd
Egyptians, but carry things for the credit of
The Mathematiques honourably; my Lady hath
Given the Caldean her Nativity, who is to conſult
With the Ephemerides, and give account how
The Stars wil dispoſe of her.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: We ſhall know all our fortunes then.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The worſt of his train can diſcipher hands,
Tell foreheads.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: And Noſes.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: One at the firſt ſight did but whiſper to my
Ladies Gentlewoman, and ſhe did ſo bluſh
Through her Tiffany.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: That's no great matter, I have ſeen one bluſh
Through a Plaiſter of Paris.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: A kind of French painting Sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Well ſaid Piperollo;
I have entertain'd him; but my Lady.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Caldean
Pleaſes me, I long to hear my fortune,
If it be good he ſhall have a reward
To cheriſh his great Art, and worth my bounty;
What if my Stars ſhould frown?
Didſt bid 'em follow?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: They are all ready Madam.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Muſicall knaves.

div.stage: Enter Longino, Rancone, Pacheco, Strozzo, in queint diſguiſes.

l.hi: Here take their glorious throne; may be
That is the God of Archerie,
But ſoft, and gentle as your heart,
Court it with flame, and rich perfume,
To light, and ſweeten, not conſume.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Not the Caldean come yet? my thoughts are
Inflam'd with fierce deſire to know my Deſtiny;
You have skill Gentlemen; but I'l expect
The judgment of your Maſter on my Fate;
When the great man of art returns acquaint me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come my friends, lets loſe no time; Sir.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I am for you to the extent of my Art Signiour.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: If it pleaſe you, let me peruſe your hand.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Pleaſe you to examine my Palm; can you
Tell me learned Sir, what is paſt?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You know that already.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Twill be a ſatisfaction to me, if you can
Make it appear, that you know ſomething
In that point.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: A Fracture in the Mercuriall line, and the
Mount of Saturn ill characted I you are
Neer a misfortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Jupiters Mount is well form'd and colour'd
A Croſs conſpicuous, the Suns Mount well
Figur'd, and linea ſolis, without any interſection,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your Iudgment upon that Sir?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: More Anticks yet? What Nation have we here,
Fortune flingers!

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.l: You ſhall know yours immediately.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Her houſe is open for theſe Mountebanks,
Cheaters, and Tumblers, that can foiſt and flatter
My Lady Gugaw; Every office open,
When Poor men that have worth and want an Alms,
May periſh ere they paſs the Porters lodge;
What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: One of the Mathematicians noble Signior.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Mathematicians? Mungrell,
How durſt thou take that learned name upon thee?
You are one of thoſe knaves that ſtroul the Country,
And live by picking worms out of fools fingers.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And ſomething out of your trunks, my reverend Cato.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Buſie the raskals are, how the rogues ſtink?
I'l ſend your Regiment a Quarter-maſter.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Now to my other gameſter.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You have been—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: In your ear—a theef.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: He has a Devil; good Sir not too loud.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And you ſhall be—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Hang'd I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Let me ſee tother hand.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Shall it ſcape with burning?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You ſhall be a Lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A Lord.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hum, yes, a Lord infallibly.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You ſhall be a Knight Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Of the theeves Order, and wear my rich
Collar of hemp; is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: An honourable Knight, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A Lord— Pray give your opinion.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Your hand— you ſhall be a right worſhipfull—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: One of your tribe told me I ſhould be a Lord.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And ſhall be us'd accordingly, Lords are tranſitory.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Let me ſee tother hand. I marry Sir, this line
Cleeres the doubt, and markes you right
Honourable, which makes up the tother half
Of your fortune Signior, theſe two parallell lines
From the dexter angle to be the Mount of Sol,
Has made all plain, you muſt be a Lord.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: He has given you a very good reaſon Sir,
A man can have but half his fortune in one
Hand, and two right worſhipfulls makes up
One right honourable; theſe are rare fellowes,
I am predeſtinate to be a Knight,
The Stars may do their pleaſure, I obey.
This ſhould be the Caldean.

div.stage: Enter Frapolo, Castruchio he whiſpers to the reſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have narrowly obſerved the Caſtle, and
Where the treaſure lies, I know my Lady
In honour will entertain us this night, and
When they are aſleep wee'l take our opportunity
To rifle her Exchequer, boyes, mean time
Let me alone to humour her proud Nature;
I will ſo claw her ambition.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the interim, I'l put a queſtion to
His Aſtrology. Sir, If you pleaſe till my Lady
Return to ſatisfie her Seward, and oblige him
By your Art, one of your under Mathematicks
Has given me a Comfortable Deſtinie.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Your hand. When were you born?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: A Lord—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No Matter, Venus in the Aſcendent with
Sol, being Lady of your ſeventh; hum, hum,
With Iupiter, deſignes you to be a Lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: They all agree; the miracle of learning!
One queſtion more I beſeeth you Sir, I
Am to ride with my Man to receive my Ladies
Rent to morrow through the Forreſt—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Go to.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Now I deſire to know, whether we ſhall be
Rob'd in our return or no?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What time do you think preciſely to come
Back Sir, for we ſhould know the very minute.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Money is ready Sir, and we do purpoſe,
In your ear—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes, you ſhall be rob'd, ther's nothing in
Nature to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Will they kill us, and pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No, they ſhall not kill you, they ſhall only
Take your money, and break your pate, that
Will be all.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Why let 'em rob us Sir, the loſs of our Money
Will be an evidence of our preferment, and you
May have more aſſurance to be a Lord, and
I of my Knighthood— My Lady Sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Madam, the Stars ſhine with their full beams
Upon you, Who by me their interpreter, ſalute
You with a glorious fortune: For Leo's Lord of your
Horoſcope in the right angle of heaven, and a royall
Fixt Sar calld Regulus, or the Lions hart, culminating
With him, and a naturall reception between Mars,
And Sol Lord of the tenth, being in the firſt with
Mercury and Venus in the houſe of honour, beſides
A Conjunction of Iupiter and Luna in Piſces, in
The houſe of Mariage. I muſt give Iudgment.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I ſhall beſeech your cleerer language.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You ſhall be Married to a Prince, it is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: A Prince?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: May not I come to be a Lord then?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: And I a Knight?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: When ſhall I ſee him?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: He ſhall within few days viſit your Caſtle,
Drawn hither with the fame of your perſon,
And bravery. I need not inſtruct you to entertain
Him with State and Ceremony becoming his
Excellence, but if he Court you not into his arms,
I will renounce the Stars, and ſay there is no
Truth in Aſtrology.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How my thoughts ſwel already.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She has ſwallowe'd it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Give him five hundred Piſtolets.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Do not wrong ſo much
One that does honour you; as I bribe not
The Stars to tell me their Decrees, I dare not
For money ſell their Secrets, and if any
That have relation to me preſume
To take a Iulio—

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: By no means Madam—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I like it that no Mercenary ends
Guide 'em to flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Is not that a March?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: If it entrench not too far upon your art,
This Prince, Sir, has a Name.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And rules this Province,
Ferneſe is a Bachelour.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Prince of Parma?
My bloud refines in every vein already,
Dull heavy Souls that are content to drudge
In humble thoughts.

div.stage: Enter Longino and whiſpers to Frapolo.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I Fear we are betraid;
The Countries up and marching to the Caſtle,
We may be all ſurpriz'd let us to, horſe—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Deny not, Sir, this night an entertainment,
Such as my Caſtle yields, it ſha'not ſpread
To receive gueſts more welcome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A Drum Madam.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Muſt we not ſtay and rob the houſe to night?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Madam, my art foretells I cannot be
Safe to remain here, at my return
I wo'not baulk your Caſtle, i'th' mean time
Cheriſh high thoughts, your Stars do call you Princeſs,
So kiſſing your fair hand—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Make me not ſo unhappy.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: There is no diſpute with Deſtinie,
I take my humble leave, away to horſe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: This more amazeth me, what danger ſhould
Provoke this haſt, if it prove their concernment,
I muſt believe they do converſe with Fate,
And truſt to them as Oracles; a Princeſs?
Was not my Soul Propheticall?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam, ſome accident hath rais'd your tenants,
They march in fury this way, in ſtrange poſtures
And Arms, as if they came to ſtorm the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Madam, we are all undone, the Clubs are up,
Your Tenants are turn'd Rebels, and by this time
Entred the Hall; and threaten to ſurprize
I know not whom; But the Caldean, and
His troop are vaniſh'd, they foreſaw this tempeſt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What ſhould this mean?
Come on you men of luſty Chine, Dear Lady
Be not affrighted, Captain of thy Guard
Am I, thy naturall Tenant, and thy Vaſſall;
Where be theſe Sunburnt Aethiopians?
I wo'not leave one Canting Rogue alive.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What Aethiopians, what Canting Rogues?
Do not your Clounſhips know me?
Know our Princeſs?
We honour thee, and riſe in thy defence;
Where be theſe theeves? we heard there were
A Regiment, that came to Cheat and Plunder.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Y'are a Knot
Of knaves and fools, and ſhall repent this inſolence;
You that command in chief, good Captain Bumbard,
May teach your Raggamuffins face about,
Was it your ſtratagem to fright my gueſts?
Your Uncle told us Madam, and commanded.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Was it his plot? he's ſtill my enemy.
Pard on us Madam,
We came ſimply hither to do you ſervice;
Kneel, or we ſhall all be ſtript out of our Tenements.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: My Uncle has abus'd you,
But this ſubmiſſion takes our anger off,
Continue dutifull to my Commands,
And you ſhall be remembred; Piperollo—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I know the Buttery Madam; follow me,
It is my Ladies pleaſure you be drunk,
And thank her grace ye keep your Copiholds;
Dee you bring up the rear, I'l march in front.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Paſſion O'me, it is to great an honour,
Refuſe a man of your high bloud and name,
That Courts her honourably? I could beat her.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis not impoſſible at my return
To find a change. I muſt to Court agen.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The horſes my Lord are ready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What a Baggage 'tis, ſhees all for the Nunnery,
She ſha not have her will, I'l undo my ſelf
But I'l deſtroy this Modeſty; if I could
But make her proud there were ſome hope on her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My Lord you may command, but how unfit,
I am to manage this affair.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thou haſt a powerfull Language, it prevail'd
On me when I firſt ſaw thee, ſince which time
I have not deſerv'd unkindly from thee, and
This truſt ſpeaks more than Common favour.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Make me his advocate to Angellina?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: My Lord, if you can ſtill preſerve theſe thoughts
Of honour to us, leave her to my Counſell.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Moſt cheerfully, I am not deſperate;
This Gentleman I'l leave to wait upon her,
Who is privy to my Counſells, and affection.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip hath found truſt in him, but that
Sha'not excuſe my care, to make her know
Her happineſs, and the Honour of our Family,
By meeting your commands. She's here.
Franceſcina tell me, what hope of your Miſtreſs?
How does thy Counſell work? does ſhe pray leſs
Then ſhe was wont? or liſten now and then
When thou talk'ſt wantonly, does ſhe ſmile upon't?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Between our ſelves, I put her to a ſmiling
Bluſh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ſaid ſhe, tell me on thy modeſty,
When ſhe found her dear delight, the legend
Of the Saints remov'd, and Ovids tales of
Jupiter put in the place?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She ſaid, that Iupiter
Was a moſt ſenſuall Heretick, and the ceſtus
That Venus wore was not St. Francis girdle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How did ſhe like the picture of Leander,
Swimming the Helleſpont upon his back?
How that of Cleopatra kiſſing Antony?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She Says that Queen was none of the poor Clares,
But one bread up in black Aegyptian Darkneſs;
All I can ſay, ſhe is not deſperate,
I ſing no Anthems to her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ſays ſhe to her dancing Maſter?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She is paſt her honor; that's a precious fellow,
She'l laugh to ſee him gamboll with his limbs,
His head flies like a Ball about the room,
You'd think he were at Tennis with it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Though in the guilt and knowledge of my own
Defects, to anſwer ſuch an honourable
Eſteem of me, I dare not yet preſume
To meet it; I ſhall want no pious thoughts
For this ſo great a bounty to a poor
Deſertleſſe Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hang your pious thoughts
And love my Lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Not for the wealth of Parma
Should my Cauſe force one cloud upon her face
Or put her eys to the expence of tears,
It ſhall be argument for me to hope,
If ſhe accept this youth to wait upon her,
Who may in ſome auſpicious hour, prepare me
A gentle ſeat within her heart, mean time
I leave upon your Virgin lip the faith,
Of your true Servant Lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'l attend you
To horſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Poor miſerable maid,
Faln now beneath the pity of thy ſelf;
My heart, on which ſo late a flame of Heaven
Stream'd comfort in my holy reſolutions,
Is fil'd with love, but not of Contarini,
Whoſe paſſion may deſerve anothers welcome.
I prethee Franceſcina take thy Lute
And let me hear thy voice.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I can ſing Venus and Adonis to you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Or will you hear the pleaſant Dity
How fair Caliſto firſt became a Nunne.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I prethee do not name a Nun, the flame
That I feel here deſerves no Veſtall name.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I'l do my beſt to fit you,
Ther's no ſuch tool in nature as a Chambermaid
To work upon her Miſtreſs.

div.head: ACT IIII.
div.stage: Enter Frapolo, Longino, Strozzo, Pacheco, with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: IT was a fatall buſineſs to loſe ſuch
An opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: My Lady was wound up ſo rarely.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: We were betraid for certain; 'twas high
Time to ſcud, and get into our Territories;
Now we are ſafe in our Grots, ſecure as
The Minotaur, and keep the clew of our
Own Labyrinths.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: We loſt a rare deſign, but in my opinion,
Tis better ſcouting here with our heads on,
Than have 'em carryed in by Clowns at the Court rate.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The ignorant Rogues would nere ha 'ſold
Them to their worth.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And they dare as ſoon venter upon Hell,
As Shoot their heads into this Furnace.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: But this Claridiana ſha'not ſcape ſo,
I am reſolv'd to viſit her again, and I am
Glad I prepar'd another expectation, theſe
Difficulties ſhall make our next attempt
More glorious.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thoſe ſhapes will conjure up the Bores again.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: She does expect the Caldean.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Hang the Caldean. I have a new device
Shall ſcoure the Caſtle, and make Dame
Guinever with all her pride, thank and adore
The invention.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: How dear Frapolo? how?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Scout and diſcover, Strozzo.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I ſee but two men coming down the Hill.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Cannot their worſhips travell with leſs noiſe?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: They durſt not be ſo confident without a number,
'Tis good to be ſecure, the noiſe approaches,
Lets to our ſhells.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Do you lie perdue ſtill.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do not like their confidence, theſe may be
The enemies ſcouts, lets non engage to ſoon
For fear of a reſerve. The State has threatned
To ſend their Vermin forth.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Obſcure: cloſe, cloſe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?
Thou haſt a mind to be rob'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I would have art maintain'd in reputation,
You know my Lady is to be a Princeſs,
And you muſt be a Lord, and I be dubbed,
But if we be not rob'd, I know not how
To truſt the Mathematicks or the Stars;
I am afraid all the Bandits are hang'd,
A thouſand Piſtols ſhould not fear to travell.

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.l: It is not wiſdom to proclaim our charge,
Though I could be content to be a Lord,
I am not over hearty, theeves are theeves,
And life is precious, prethee lets make haſt.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Illo ho ho,
Think upon your honour, are there no Gentlemen?
No wanting Gentlemen that know how to ſpend
A quantity of Gold?
There is no thief in Nature.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The Gentleman
Is very merry, they that mean well, and
Have their wits about 'em, do not uſe
To call upon our Tribe. This is a plot,
A very plot, and yet the Coaſt is cleer,
Now I may reach their voice.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It wo'not be, was ever men diſtreſt ſo?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Come we are well yet Piperollo, if
The Stars Decree our robbery, it will follow.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I pray Sir lets ſit down here, as you hope to
Be a Lord, we muſt do our endeavour and help
The Fates. Do but hear reaſon Sir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: 'Tis my proud Madams Steward, and our quondam
Fellow thief; they were told their fortunes
To be rob'd; Here had been a purchaſe loſt
If I had not lain perdue. You ſhall be
Diſpatcht preſently, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.l: What's that? I do not like that tune.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Hum, I am not in love with that Quailpipe.
I could dwindle, but that I have a ſtrong
Faith in the Mathematicks. Theeves and be
Thy Will.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: If they ſhould cut our throats now—this is
Your folly; would I were off.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Would I were a Knight in an embroidered
Diſh clout. Have a good heart Sir, ther's
No more to be ſaid in't, let the Stars take
Their courſe, 'tis my Ladies money—and if
We be rob'd, we are ſo much the neerer to preferment.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Ah ſweet Gentlemen take but the Money—

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis ready told; nay, nay, we are friends;
Give us but a Mote under your hands for
My Ladies ſatisfaction, that you have received
It Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You need not trouble your ſelves to tell it Gentlemen,
It is all right.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: So, ſo, wee'l take your words.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I ſhould know that vizard, the garments
That you wear too I have ſeen Old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Does he know you? cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: No Sir, I do not know him, nor any man, nor
My ſelf, I was not once rob'd before, neither
Did I help any man to rob my own Father and Mother;
I knew no Cedar cheſt I, I diſclaim it, nor
Was any man that I know left bound for the
Money; ye are all honeſt Gentlemen,
And I congratulate our good fortune, that you
Came ſo luckily in the very nick, we had carried
Home the money elſe in good ſadneſs— Sir,
We are made for ever—rare Mathematicians!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What's that you talk ſirra of Mathematicians?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It pleaſed ſome of the learned tribe to viſit
My Lady not long ſince, but they are well I
Hope, they told us we ſhould be rob'd, and
'Tis done; bleſſed Caldean!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What became on 'em?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: They ſcap'd a ſcouring, for my Ladies Cinicall
Uncle, in meer malice to learning, rais'd
The Towns upon em, perſwading the hobbinolls
They came to rob the houſe; but honored
Be the Stars, they brought 'em off at the
Back gate.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: They ſeem honeſt fellows, let 'em live, and Paſs.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: We humbly thank you Gentlemen, come Piperollo.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: And yet, now I remember, there wants a
Circumſtance, my pate is not broke yet,
That was a Clauſe the Caldean was a little
Out.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I had forgot, will you be prating ſirra?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Now tis done, I thank you, dear Gentlemen,
I thank you, go forth and be a Knight;
Mathematician I adore thee, it bleeds;
Where are you Sir? all is compleat, and my
Head is broke according to prophecie. Oh
Admirable Caldean!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: We have not loſt all my Ladies money, but
To your plot Frapolo.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: This hath ripend it, and I appear a
Blazing Star already.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What's the myſtery?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You know I am your Prince.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: 'Tis Acknowledged.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We will in State viſit the proud Paulina,
I am the Prince Farneſe, and you
Are all my Lords and privy Counſellors
Bear up for honour of your Prince.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I apprehend it, 'tis a moſt rare deſign,
She will be mad to meet it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Will you marry her?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I cannot tell, there may be a neceſſity,
But when I ha' the wench, her Plate and Jewels,
And other ſums, I have caſt already whither.
We muſt tranſport our ſelves—wee'l divide all.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: And the wench too?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No not the wench, untill I caſt the Concubine;
Remember who I am, the choice of fleſh
Is my prerogative; no murmuring,
You ſhall provide our Robes.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Now we are rogues to purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am your Prince, and the worſt theef
A States-mans.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Where is Vergerio?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Madam? I prethee leave that folly,
I am no Lady, call me Angellina.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I'l call you Madam, 'tis a name in faſhion,
What do you want to juſtifie that title?
Have you not Beauty, Jewels, Gold at pleaſure?
Fine Cloathes, high Food, and men as motley, as
The Ambaſſadors to wait? does not your Uncle
Allow you all that can make up a Lady?
Pardon my boldneſs Madam, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What are theſe?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The Gentlewomen were commended, Madam,
Moſt excellent in their Art about great Ladies;
And come to tender you their humble ſervice.
Moſt proud if you accept our duties Madam.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Look you, they're proud already, they have nothing
But their trade to live on; ſhe with the face
Spotted with Ermins, hath been late in France,
And knows the mode to a Mathematicall point,
She has the theory of Song, but loſt
The practick part by ſitting up a nights;
She danceth ſtill, can talk in ſeverall languages,
And has the art of every game, to inſtruct
A novice Lady—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To loſe time.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And what
Age, do you think the other Gentlewoman
Carries? that ſimpers ſo? the miracle
Of Painting! ſhe preſents ſcarce five and twenty,
But if you credit Church Records, ſhe numbers
But five ſhort of threeſcore, Medea had
No charmes like her, to preſerve youth, and beauty;
She hath the art of making eys, new hair,
And Ivory teeth, hath skill in making fruitfull,
And is an excellent Midwife; ſhe hath cur'd
A man that had no Noſe, and a Court-Lady
That had no Tongue.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Theſe are tranſcendent qualities;
Since tis my Uncles pleaſure, they may wait,
But not to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who's that knocks ſo modeſtly?
'Tis not your Dancing-Maſter, nor the Doctor,
They have more confidence.
'Tis the Parſons Nephew, come from the Univerſity,
Some ſay a pretty Schollar, and a wit;
Hath an Ambition to kiſs your hand
And tender his firſt fruits.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Some Poetry.
By any means Madam, you muſt be flatter'd,
Great Ladies cannot live els.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let him enter.

sp.speaker: Sch
sp.l: Darling of beauty, faireſt Angellina,
Thus low the Muſes bow, and ſend by me
An abſtract of your ſelf; oh make the Paper
More white by kiſſing your fair hand, and with
Your breath, like a ſoft Weſtern gale, perfume
Theſe lines created in your praiſe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What's heer?— I am
A ſtranger to you Sir, and to your language,
Theſe words have no relation to me;
I pity men of your high fancy, ſhould
Diſhonour their own names, by forming ſuch
Prodigious ſhapes of beauty in our ſex.
If I were really what you would commend,
Mankind would flie me; get a Painter Sir,
And when he has wrought a woman by your fancy,
See if you know her again; were it not fine,
If you ſhould ſee your Miſtreſs without hair?
Dreſt only with thoſe glittering beams you talk of?
Two Suns inſtead of Eys, and they not melt
The forhead made of Snow; no Cheeks, but two
Roſes inoculated upon a Lillie?
Between, a pendent Alablaſter Noſe?
Her Lips cut out of Corall, and no Teeth,
But Strings of Pearl; Her Tongue a Nightingales;
Her chin a rump of Ivory; and ſo forth?
Would not this ſtrange Chimera fright your ſelf?
And yet you take the boldneſs to preſent us,
And think we muſt applaud, and thank you for
Our ſelves made Monſters by your art; no more
Of this for ſhame; loſe not your time and honour
In this fantaſtick Idoll; you will ſay,
The world is peeviſh, and not kind to virtue;
Give him ten Piſtolets to cure his poverty,
There are good ſeeds in him and they may
Grow with ſome Cheriſhing.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: You are enough
To vindicate your Sex, I ſhall not bluſh
To write your ſtory.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You ſhall owe me Sir
An Anagram, and a Poeſy too for
My next Ring.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: You ſhall command my faculty,
My deareſt Abigall

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thank you ſweet Sir Roger.
Is her Ladiſhip at leaſure?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What are theſe?
We are humble ſutes Madam for your Favour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Speak your requeſt.
I am a Tailor Madam
That holds intelligence with forein Courts
To furniſh Ladies with new Faſhions.
And I have patterns of the ſtrangeſt ſhapes
That ever Ladies long'd for.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I believe it.
I have the ambition to own the name
Of your Perfumer Madam.
I your Jeweller;
What think you of that Carcanet ſweet Madam?
The Pearls are Orient, I have a Diamond
The Sultan gave one of his Concubines,
It weighes —20 caracts, if it pleaſe you Madam,
To wear it in the Court, and I'l attend
Your Ladiſhip ſix moneths hence to pay me for't;
I know your Uncle Madam.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This is his plot.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By all means take it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Excuſe me; what are you? ſpeak your deſire.
I would preſent you Madam with a pair
Of curious Spurs.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: For what uſe prethee?
For what you pleaſe, I ſee all men of trade
Apply themſelves to gain relation to you,
And I would be your Spurrier.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Do Ladies wear Spurs my friend?
They may in time, who knows what may be done,
If one great Lady would begin, they ride
Like men already; 'tis all one to me,
So I may have the Credit of your name,
And privilege to ſwell above my neighbors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: When I ſtand, Gentlemen, in need of your
Profeſſions, I'l ſend for you, i'th' mean time
You ſhall need no Solicitour.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Your Servants.
Buy a Spur.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I prethee let me not be troubled with
This kind of People Franceſcina; Ladies
Have a fine time, if they be all thus viſited.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You are rude and ſawcy fellows to intrude
So far without my Ladies licence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What makes thee ſo impatient? will they not
Be gone?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Gone? here's a new regiment is preſſing forward

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Beggers.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: And tell me I abuſe your Charity,
To keep off their Petitions; we muſt have
A Court-du-guard, I think, and Centries plac'd
At every dore.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I prethee let 'em enter.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The room will not be ſweet again this three days;
But if it be your pleaſure—know your diſtance.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The blind, and lame, what's your condition Sir?
1 As miſerable Madam as the Sea,
That ſwallow'd all my wealth, can make a man,
That once commanded thouſands, I bluſh to beg
But Nature too impatient of ſterving
Compels me to this boldneſs, you may ſoon
Peruſe my tragick ſtory there.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Good old man!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What is his loſs to you?
2 My Petition too;
A poor blind man, that hath loſt more by fire
Than his eſtate valued a thouſand times;
And 'tis but equall, fire ſhould ſpoil my eys,
That raviſh'd me of all, was precious to 'em,
A wife and pretty Children.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Burn'd?
2 All burn'd;
And what my eys cannot afford their memory
My poor heart weeps in bloud.
3 I am a Souldier
That in my Countries ſervice loſt my limbs;
I've had more lead in bullets taken from me
Than would repair ſome Steeple.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ring the bells,
That was a loud one!
3 I have given wounds have kil'd the lookers on
With horror of their gaping, and have march'd
Ten miles a day thus deep —

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: In dirt?
3 In blood.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Upon thoſe wooden leggs?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Poor ſouls! I pitty 'em, here honeſt men,
Divide this bag, and pray for my good Uncle.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Bleſſings on you, Madam.
2. Equall diviſion, come.
1. Stay, in the firſt place, I brought you hither,
Therefore my part is moſt conſiderable.
3. I'l have no Prerogative.
2. Nor I.
1. But I will.
Do not I know you both for cheating Raſcals?
Thus are good meanings cozen'd, and you ſha'not
Loſe your reward; ſend for ſome Officers.
2, 3. We are betraid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They have found their eyes and leggs again,
Neece I obſerve your Charity, but you ſee not
The inſide of theſe things, and I did mean
And hope theſe ſums might ſerve your ſelf;
Some Ladies would have conſidered
A new Gown and trinkets; Franceſcina,
I ſee little amendment, ſhe'l undo me
In pious uſes.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She has entertain'd theſe Gentlewomen.
And that young Gentleman does good upon her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I like it well, he's carefull of my Lord,
And if ſhe meet his honorable treaty,
She may learn Pride at Court, ſhould our Art fail.
She ſmiles — I wo'not interrupt 'em.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My Lady entreats the preſence of her Siſter.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do's ſhe entreat? Yes, you may viſit her
Sir if you pleaſe, I'l truſt her to your conduct.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis my ambition to attend her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Hark you,
Remember who you are, and carry things
For the credit of my heir, and one that muſt be
Right Honourable ſhortly, if I hear
Thou flout'ſt her, thou ſha't have another Gown
And Petticoat embroider'd, or but beat her
And put me to a penſion; fare you well,
Franteſcina wait, wait all upon your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No news yet of the Prince? he fill'd my dreams
Laſt night, it was a golden glorious ſlumber;
Me-thought we both were led into a Temple,
Where all our rites of Mariage were perform'd
In the preſence of a thouſand Angel-Cupids.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Twas my devotion, Madam, to preſent you
The News, I could not break my neck upon
A better cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Is the Prince come?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The Prince is at your ſervice; though I ſlipt
At Chamber door, it is my happineſs
To be the firſt Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I deſire no reward Madam, 'tis ſufficient
I know what will become of us all, you
Remember the Caldean; all has happen'd,
I thank Aſtrology.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Your money is gone, your rents have been received,
And my head broke to purpoſe; things are viſible.
My Maſter can confirm it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What's this prodigie?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam 'tis done, we have been rob'd.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: As the Caldean and the Stars would have it,
Juſt to a minute.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Rare Mathematician!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I'l hang you both,

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: You may, and be no Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Did he foretell this loſs?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Is my pate broken? Do I live, and hope
To kneel, and ſay, If pleaſe your Grace, to call
Him Lord, and anſwer to a Knight? — we're made.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Be at a diſtance,
If there be truth in the Caldeans Art,
Theſe inconſiderable loſſes are
A new preſage of my approaching greatneſs.

stage.hi: Enter Stephanio, and Longino, diſguiz • d.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: One from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His Highneſs Farneſe, Madam, greets your
Ladiſhip, and int • nds to be your Gueſt this night,

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It will be an honour
My life muſt ow him duty for.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Do not you feel a Lordſhip creep up
By your ſhort ribs?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His Grace is not far off.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Preſent the humble duty of his handmaid,
And ſay my Caſtle droops til it receive him;

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I ſhall Madam.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: We muſt prepare to meet and entertain him;
All things have been Prophetical.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: My very good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Right Worſhipfull Piperollo.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: In my pity
That ſo much innocence ſhould not be loſt
On faithleſs Contarini, I have landed
Upon your knowledge this unhappy ſecret.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Promis'd his faith to another? twas ill done,
To work my Uncle, and deſtroy my thoughts
Of a religious life.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: You may collect
Thoſe pure deſires again,
Heaven will be ſoon invited, and a ſecond
Reſolve confirm that happineſs.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: May we not,
Without ſo ſtrict forſaking of the world,
Be capable of bleſſing, and meet heaven
At laſt, though erring Nature guide ſometime
Out of the neareſt way?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes Angellina.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I muſt be no Votary,
But when you turn a Fryer then.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How Lady?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sir you have merited for this diſcovery
All that I am to ſerve you, and unleſs
You help me in this Labyrinth, I muſt
Live in deſpair of Freedom.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Any ſervice;
There's ſo much ſweetneſs in you, I could lay
My life a Sacrifice, be confident
I muſt be left of heaven, when I forſake you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And I dare truſt your Virtue with a ſecret
I have not told my Ghoſtly Father.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I know not what opinion my Lord has
of his ſmooth Advocate, but I ſhould gather
By Symptomes of my Miſtreſs, ſhe is ſick
Of the younger Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I dare not hope
This bleſſing, 'tis an honour plac'd on me
That has no value, I am a ſtranger,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You are no ſtranger here.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your Uncle too—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: May erre in his election.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But his anger—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My prayer and tears may ſoften.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Do not dreſs
Your eys with ſorrow Angellina, this
Too gracious an influence upon
Your ſervant muſt command my utmoſt duty.
Upon this white hand I breath out my heart,
And when I pay affection to another
Miſtreſs, in your revenge, her beauty blaſt me!
But we may be obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Be all my guide.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: This muſt be manag'd wiſely, we are loſt els.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We are now arriv'd the Caſtle Franceſcina.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We attend.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I am •• ſcur'd ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My life on't.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Here are great preparations, and the people
Flock as to ſee ſome triumph, this Paulina
Will be ador'd i'th' Country.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But her Siſter,
With an extreme of ſweetneſs and humility
Will take the wonder off, ſhe ſo tranſcends.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Your words fall from you,
I have obſervd my Lord, with too much paſſion;
She's but a woman, and may be no miracle,
When a clear eye is Judge.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir I owe
All that I am in fortune, name and greatneſs
Unto your perſon, next whom, give me leave
To ſay I rate no expectation
Equall to be her ſervant, yet I find
Her cold to thoſe deſires, that court her with
All honour, I ſhall humbly beg, your grace
When you converſe, will interpoſe your favour,
And by your Mediation perfect all
That can be nam'd my happine • s.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: You expreſs
A ſtrong Captivity in ſo ſmall acquaintance;
Well my Lord truſt to me; is this her Caſtle?
By your favour Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Speak quickly whats your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Is this Paulina's Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Plain Paulina? and is this her Caſtle?
My friend you want ſome breeding, ſhe that owes
This Palace, for a Prince hath made it ſo,
Is not far off; turn your eys backward Sir,
And tell your ſelf without a perſpective
What man is coming towards us?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Worthy Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Put of your hats and hear his name, Farneſe
The Prince of Parma's there, I kiſt his hand,
My breath is ſince the ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: The Prince, where?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: You'l find him with my Lady whom he came
To viſit, if you'l promiſe to be drunk,
Take what's a ſecret yet, he comes to marry her,
Or ther's no truth in Stars, ſhe is to be
His ſpouſe; farewell, and thank my worſhip heartily.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This fellow's mad!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: He kiſt the Princes hand,
What myſtery is this?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: See, they approach.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am not loſt ſure in this cloud, they march
In State this way.

div.stage: Enter Frapolo, Paulina, a Train of Gallants and Ladies, Vergerin, Angellina.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How, an Impoſtor?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sure I know the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Conceal it yet.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: The Prince of Parma Sir.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: This will be worth obſerving.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Do we not both dream? that Paulina?
How diſdainfully ſhe moves?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That's her younger Siſter upon whom
Vergerio waits.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: He knows I am the Prince.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How do you like her Sir?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ha? tis not fit to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Does ſhe not anſwer my Character?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: On my heart a fair one?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray tell me how you like her Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Not yet.
I am loſt in wonder of her ſweetneſs. Bid
Vergerio bring her to Antonio's;
I'l be his gueſt to night.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: I ſhall obey Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Make room for the Prince, fellows bear back;
You are not to be Knighted friend I take it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Thus can the flame of Heaven with ſubtill art,
Leave the skin whole, yet quite conſume the heart.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: MY Neece has had a pretty warm night on't,
'Tis a bold knave to take the Prince upon him
I did believe the noyes, and was conſidering
How to contrive my peace with her good grace.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You have no fear to ſuffer now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thank
Your Lordſhip, that has made my houſe and knowledge
So fortunate, by the preſence of our great
Farneſe, 'tis an honour makes me young;
And yet this Raſcal troubles me, that durſt
Come in the Princes name, and charge my Neece
So home too; Is't not Treaſon Sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Of higheſt nature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him then taſt the Law; yet I commend
His Spirit, that would ſcorn to die for Felonie,
And when his head goes off, the ſhame and grief
May help to break her heart: I do not love her,
And then my Girl, my Angellina's heir,
And you her Lord and mine.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My hopes are fair,
The Prince himſelf having vouchſaf'd to be
My Advocate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He muſt command all here.
'Tis a good Prince, and loves you well, and let me
Without boaſt, tell you my Lord, ſhe brings
No common Blood, though we live dark i'th' Country
I can derive her from the great Urſini,
But we have been eclips'd.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Contarint leave us. You may ſtay Antonio;
Is't not an honour to your Family
A Prince ſhould court your Neece into his arms?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs, 'tis good enough for ſuch
A Baggage, they will make together Sir,
