A moſt excellent ſhew upon the Scaffold.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: The Impoſtor, and Paulina's pride, takes off
Your underſtanding; I do court your Neece
Fair Angellina.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: And as becomes a Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Grace is merry.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I know not, but there's Magick in her eyes.

sp.speaker: An:
sp.l: Magick? and ſhe be a Witch, I ha'done with her.
Does he love Angelina? Pleaſe your Highneſs—
Do you affect this Girl?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Religiouſly.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And have you all your Princely wits about ye?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: This Language is but coarſe. I tell you Sir
The Virgin muſt be mine.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Your Whore?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: My Princeſs.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That's another matter.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Shew your obedience,
You have commands upon her as a Father.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I know not what to ſay, but I'l perſwade;
Hark you Neece, you hear what the Prince ſays,
'Tis now no time to think of Nunneries.
Be rul'd then, and love ſomebody; if you have
Promis'd my Lord, I ſay make good that promiſe,
If not, the Prince is worth conſidering.
The Gentleman will make you a round Iointure.
If thou beeſt free, love him, to vex thy Siſter,
Who may upon ſubmiſſion be receiv'd
To Grace, and riſe in time a Madam Nurſe
To your heir apparent. I have done my duty.
But this is no great honeſty, to cheat
My Lord. I ſee the greateſt men are fleſh
And blood, our ſouls are much upon a making;
All men that are in love deal with the Devil,
Only with this difference, he that dotes
Upon a Woman is abſolutely poſſeſt;
And he that loves the leaſt is haunted
With a Familiar.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Old Fabio Sir your Tenant, with much buſineſs
Jn's face, deſires to ſpeak with you, I could hardly
Keep him from preſſing in, his Wife he ſayes
Is Lunatick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We ſhall all be mad ſhortly,
Where is the Knave?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: I dare do Sir as much to ſhew my duty
As any Maid alive; I dare dye for you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And yet you dare not love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Not in that ſenſe
You invite me to.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: My Courtſhip carries
No ſtain to fright you, what I have propounded
Is worth the Ambition of a greater Lady;
Though you profeſs ſo liberally, I find
Your cunning, and becauſe I have ſo much
Deſcended from my Title, you aſſume
This unbecomming Nicety, take heed,
I can be angry.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: As you are a Man
That paſſion may come neer you Sir; and as
You are my Prince, you may command my death
To follow and Appeaſe it, but you ſaid you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I doe, if you can wiſely entertain it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then you muſt love my honor,
A Virgins wealth, for every honeſt Man
Or Woman has an honor, and that has
Engag'd my heart already by a Contract;
This tye diſſolv'd with juſtice, I ſhould kneel
To ask your Princely favour.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am anſwer'd.
Who waits? call my Lord Contarini hither.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: You might have mock'd another perſon,
And not have made me a ridiculous ſtory
To your Miſtreſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Engage me to mediation for her love,
With a pretence how much my act ſhould honor
Your faint hopes, when you are conſcious of a
Contract, already paſt between you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Contract Sir?
She never yet gave me any language
Did promiſe hope, ſhe ſtill concluded me
With going to a Cloiſter.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: How's this fair one?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It is moſt ſure I am contracted.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Vergerio your Lordſhips Agent.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That boy betray me?
In whom I took delight, made him my friend,
He play the Traytor? I'l be reveng'd upon
His heart.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Contain your paſſion Contarini,
Her beauty had apower a bove my friendſhip,
It well might ſhake his faith, and yet'tis ſtrange.
Call in Vergerio.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have heard all,
And come to meet my ſentence. You're a Prince
Gainſt whom I dare not lift a thought; I ſee
What ſtorm is riſing, yet let this, great Sir,
Invite your mercy to me, I have made
No breach againſt your love, and that which wa •
My fault to his, may be excus'd, by what
He felt himſelf love not to be reſiſted.
This Virgin I lay claim to, and her vowes
No Subject muſt compell me to reſigne;
But if the Prince think me unfit, and call
This treaſure from my boſome, and can place
His love, where I ſo chaſtly have delighted,
I will not keep a thought that ſhall repine,
When I am miſerable in her abſence,
But give my intereſt cheerfully; to you,
My Lord, I anſwer, I have made no treſpaſs,
And ſhall, ſo pleaſe your highneſs to be Iudge,
Make it appear.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Was ever ſuch an impudence?
This preſence does protect him, I ſhould els
Write treaſon on his heart; But Angellina
I pity thy undoing, how canſt thou
Expect a truth from him, betrays his Maſter?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: My Lord, you have been faulty ſure, and this
(not worthy to be call'd a loſs of me)
Was meant by Providence to wake your faith,
That's owing to another.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Poſſible?
The Vice-roy of Sicilies Daughter? Pulcheria.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pulcheria here?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Here Contarini.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ha, prov'd a Woman, oh my ſhame and folly!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon my too much love, that made me fear
You had forgot Pulcheria, though you left
Your vowes and me at Sicily, when you were
Embaſſadour from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Whence embarqu'd
Thou brought'ſt me news Pulcheria was dround,
And thou for her ſake entertain'd my ſervant,
Welcome, at once receive me and forgive me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I had your promiſe, were this contract void
In honour, nor will take from my own merit
To think when your conſiderate thoughts come home,
You can pretend excuſe to your own happineſs,
Which leſt you may ſuſpect, let us in ſtate
Viſit Paulina, and unmask that counterfeit
Which hath uſurp'd our name.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir we attend you,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This bleſſing muſt require a ſpacious ſoul,
Mine is too narrow to receive.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I am not yet created honourable.

sp.speaker: Fi.
sp.l: Sir, things muſt have their time, but will his highneſs
Remove ſo ſuddenly, and carry my Lady
To th' Court with him? tis a moſt ſweet young Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Order was given to pack up her plate,
Her gold and Jewels, for he means to have
Tiltings and triumphs when he comes to Parma.

sp.speaker: Fi.
sp.l: There it is fit we ſhould expect our honours.
I will attend the Prince.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior Lu • io.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your good Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray tell my Lady, I would kiſs her hand,
And ſhall preſent news will ſecure their welcome.
I come from the Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince my Lord?
He is within—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A ſmall march off the Caſtle, and commanded
Me to prepare her, that he comes to be
Her gueſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Lord, I will acquaint ſome of the bed-chamber, but,
When did your Lordſhip ſee his Highneſs?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I left him at the Park gate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is the neareſt way unleſs his highneſs
Have leap'd a window, or can walk inviſible.
Your Lordſhip may have ſome conceit. I'l go Sir.

sp.speaker: Pi
sp.l: What is the meaning that ther's ſuch a guard
Upon our Caſtle? 'tis beſiedg'd, and no man
Suffer'd go forth; this is ſome Lord or other
By his ſtradling.

div.stage: Enter Lucio, Longino, Strozzo, and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: From the Prince? that he?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis as I tell you Sir, ther's a little army,
Surrounds the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: They have no order from his highneſs.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: We are betraid agen.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Sir, would you ſpeak with the Prince?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why have you ſuch a thing within the Caſtle?
Who dares be ſo much Traitour to uſurpe
That title? Wher's that Puppet, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That is his Secretary.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The reſt are Lords and Privie Counſellors.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: We are undone.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tis he, the very he, I dare not look on him;
Oh for an impudence worth a Chronicle,
To out ace him now, it were a poſſible thing,
If People would believe—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'l tell my Lady, they are vaniſh'd; hum,
I do not like that face.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Come hither fellow, whom do you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What Prince have you within?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: The prince of Darkneſs.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: a Knight o'th' Poſt, the Peſtle is too honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where is your Excellent Lady?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have a gueſs
If things go on, as I ſuſpect, ſhe will be —

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: At her wits end very ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An ingenious fellow?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I have convers'd a little with the Mathematicks,
Sir, Who is that Gentlewoman, not that I am ignorant,
But to ſatisfie a doubt?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: She is one that may be
The Prince of Parma's Lady, when the Prieſt
Hath done his Office.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: If I be not miſtaken
Here comes the Princeſſe, that is Angellina
The younger Siſter.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It is my wonder you that have the face
And garb of Gentlemen, ſhould dare to be
So inſolent, to affront our perſon,
And his, to whom your hearts and knees owe reverence.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Command the Impoſtor forth,
Seize on the Traitors.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: His Grace will be here preſently, fear not Madam,
I would venter a Neck-breaking at ſome window,
And be content to crawl away a Cripple;
But there's no hope to ſcape the Multitude
That will be ſcrambling for my limbs. Great Sir,
I challenge the privilege of the laſt Bando,
He that can bring Frapolo the chief Bandit,
Beſide what was proclam'd other reward,
Shall have free pardon for all paſt-offences;
To that Grace I appeal, and here produce

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: This amazeth me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Can you ſtand
The dazeling Sun ſo long, and not be ſtruck
Blind for this bold affront? what wildneſs brought you
In multitudes to fright my happy peace,
And this good Ladies, my moſt vertuous Conſort?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He bears up ſtill!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Have all my cares and watchings to preſerve
Your lives, and deareſt liberties, deſerv'd
This ſtrange return, and at a time when moſt
Your happineſs is concern'd, ſince by our Mariage
With this ſweet Lady, full of grace and beauty,
You may expect an Heir to bleſs your Countrey.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Will you ſuffer him?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis time your Prince were dead, and when I am
Companion to my Fathers duſt, theſe tumults
Fomented by ſeditious men, that are
Weary of Plenty, and delights of Peace,
Shall not approach to interrupt the calm
Good Princes after Death enjoy. Go home,
I pray depart, I rather will ſubmit
To be depos'd, than wear a power or title
That ſhall not all be dedicate to ſerve you;
My life is but the gift of Heaven, to waſt it
For your dear ſakes, my People are my Children,
Whom I am bound in Nature and Religion
To cheriſh and protect. Perhaps you have
Some grievance to preſent, you ſhall have juſtice
Againſt the proudeſt here; I look not on
Nobility of Birth. Office, or Fortunes,
The pooreſt ſubject has a Native Charter
And a Birth-right to th' Laws, and Common wealth,
Which with an equall, and impartial ſtream,
Shall flow to every boſom.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Pious Prince!

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am at a loſs to hear him; ſure I am
Farneſe, if I be not loſt by the way.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Stand off Gentlemen, — let me ſee — which?
Hum! this — no, th'other. Hum! ſend for a Lion
And turn him looſe, he wo'not hurt the true Prince.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Do not you know me Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, I know you too well, but it ſtands not
With my honor; what compoſition?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Who am I? Gentlemen, how dare ye ſuffer
This thing to talk? if I be your Farneſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ſay I am the Prince,

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Prince of what?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Of Rogues, and pleaſe thy Excellence.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You muſt excuſe, I can hold out no longer
Theſe were my Subjects Sir, and if they find
Your Mercy, I'm but one, whoſe head remov'd,
Or nooz'd, this Lady will be ſoon a Widdow,
Whom I have not deceiv'd, 'twas her Ambition
To go no leſs than Prince, and now you have one,
During this Gentlemans pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What ſcorn ſhall I become?

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Let him be guarded, and all his puppet Lords.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: News, news, excellent news; I ſhall leap
Out of my fleſh for joy. Sir I have undertook
For your pardon to this reverend couple,
They heard my Neece was to be maried
To the Prince, and thought it treaſon to conceal —

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Paulina is not my Neece, no blood of mine;
Where is this Lady and her Pageant Prince?
The truth is, ſhe is not Paulina, but their
Own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Poſſible? then we are both cheated.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Whom ſhe obtruded on our Family
When our Paulina died an Infant, with her,
A Nurſe to both; Does your Grace apprehend?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We do beſeech your pardon.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now Angellina thou art heir to all.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: By all this Circumſtance you are but my Siſter!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The Prince is prov'd a Prince of Theeves.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why ther's a Baggage and a Theef well met then.
I knew ſhe was a Baſtard, or a Changeling.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Where ſhall I hide my ſhame? O curſt Ambition!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give you joy Sir, my moſt illuſtrious Nephew,
Joy to thy inviſible Grace.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Thanks to our loving Uncle:

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Take hence the Traitors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sir I beſeech a pardon to their lives.
Let nothing of my ſtory be remembred
With ſuch a Tragedie, 'tis my firſt Petition.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I muſt not deny thee; all thank her Virtue;
Live you, and love that Gentlewoman; But
It were a ſin to innocence, and our honor
Would encourage Treaſon by example,
If they ſhould ſcape all Juſtice, take 'em to Cuſtody:
Frapolo, we confine you to this Caſtle,
Where If ſhe pleaſe your Bride may accompany you
Till we determine otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis ſome mercy; but
I ſhall be getting Children, and two nothings
Wo'not maintain a Family, 'twere as good
To hang me out o'th'way, 'ere Charge come on,
Or take away my tools, I ſhall be working.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Proviſion ſhall be made you ſhall not ſterve
Nor ſurfet Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Becauſe I call'd her Siſter,
I will contribute ſomething to their fortune.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: What thy own goodneſs will direct; and now
Remove the Scene to Court, to perfect there
My own, and Parma's happineſs; pride has
Met with ſevere reward, and that high juſtice
(That Governs all) though envy break with her
Own Poyſon, calls the Amazed World to ſee
What bleſſings wait upon Humility.

sp.speaker: Frapolo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, do not ſay you ſee me; I have made an eſcape from the Prince and Paulina; his graces word is but mortall, and not ſecurity enough for me; for all this Sun-ſhine he may hang me, when I come to Parma, for an example, and therefore I have choſen, rather to truſt to my legs, than a reconcil'd State-Enemy.

lg.l: Two'not be worth your glory to betray
A man diſtreſt, whom your own mercy may
Preſerve to better ſervice; rather then
Go back I'l ſtand your Iuſtice Gentlemen.
I've plaid the thief, but you, as the caſe ſtands,
May ſave or kill, my lif's now in your hands.
